verses.text: Does not wisdom call out, and understanding raise her voice?
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified as a woman speaking to all people, echoing earlier themes in Proverbs (see Prov. 1:20). The feminine imagery emphasizes receptivity and eloquence, not the gender of the attribute.

verses.text: On the heights by the way, at the crossroads she takes her stand;
verses.comment: Wisdom publicly offers herself to all, showing that God’s truth is available and not hidden away (cf. Prov. 1:21).

verses.text: Beside the gates at the entryway, at the entrance of the doors, she cries out:
verses.comment: Gates symbolize places of judgment and gathering (see Ruth 4:1). Wisdom’s call is for all, especially leaders and the community.

verses.text: "To you, O people, I call, and my voice is to the children of mankind.
verses.comment: Wisdom addresses all humanity, not only Israel, reflecting the universality of God's invitation.

verses.text: O simple ones, learn prudence; O fools, develop an understanding heart.
verses.comment: The call is to repentance and growth in virtue—wisdom seeks to transform the hearer’s heart.

verses.text: Listen, for I will speak noble things, and from my lips will come what is right.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s words carry moral authority and uprightness, for all truth flows from God.

verses.text: For my mouth will utter truth; wickedness is detestable to my lips.
verses.comment: Truth and righteousness are inseparable from true wisdom, and deceit is foreign to it.

verses.text: All the words of my mouth are righteous; there is nothing twisted or crooked in them.
verses.comment: This verse affirms that divine wisdom is wholly trustworthy, a foundation for faith and morality.

verses.text: They are all plain to those who understand, and straight to those who find knowledge.
verses.comment: Spiritual understanding opens up the apparent simplicity of wisdom’s teaching for those seeking truth.

verses.text: Receive my instruction rather than silver, and knowledge rather than choice gold.
verses.comment: Wisdom is shown to be far more valuable than material wealth, reminiscent of Solomon’s own priorities (cf. Prov. 3:14-15).

verses.text: For wisdom is better than jewels, and all that you desire cannot compare with her.
verses.comment: This echoes a recurring theme: only wisdom leads to lasting fulfillment.

verses.text: I, wisdom, dwell with prudence, and I possess knowledge and discretion.
verses.comment: Wisdom encompasses practical judgment as well as knowledge—living virtuously requires discernment.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD is to hate evil; I hate pride and arrogance, the way of evil, and perverse speech.
verses.comment: Reverence for God leads not just to intellectual assent but to moral transformation.

verses.text: Counsel and sound wisdom belong to me; I have understanding and strength.
verses.comment: Wisdom offers practical guidance and fortitude, traits linked with the Spirit's gifts (see Isa. 11:2).

verses.text: By me kings reign, and rulers decree what is just.
verses.comment: Wise leadership is recognized as instituted by God, foreshadowing the divinely ordered authority in human society (cf. Rom. 13:1).

verses.text: By me princes rule, and nobles—all who govern justly.
verses.comment: Order and justice found in society are attributed to wisdom’s influence, highlighting the importance of moral order.

verses.text: I love those who love me, and those who seek me diligently will find me.
verses.comment: God generously rewards sincere pursuit of truth (cf. Jer. 29:13, Matt. 7:7). Communion is found in seeking, not mere knowledge.

verses.text: Riches and honor are with me, enduring wealth and righteousness.
verses.comment: True prosperity comes with righteousness and wisdom, not merely material wealth.

verses.text: My fruit is better than gold, even pure gold; and my yield than choice silver.
verses.comment: Repeated emphasis on wisdom’s superiority to earthly riches highlights its eternal value.

verses.text: I walk in the way of righteousness, in the paths of justice,
verses.comment: Wisdom always leads to justice, suggesting its consistency with God’s nature.

verses.text: granting wealth to those who love me, and filling their treasuries.
verses.comment: This foreshadows the teaching that seeking wisdom (the kingdom) brings all good things (see Matt. 6:33).

verses.text: The LORD created me as the first of his works, the beginning of his acts of old.
verses.comment: This controversial verse is understood in Christian tradition as referring both to Wisdom and, in its deepest sense, to the eternal Word through whom all was made (John 1:1-3). Interpretations stress that 'created' (qanah) can mean 'possessed' or 'brought forth,' not that the Word was a creature. This supports Christ as the agent of creation—eternally begotten, not made.

verses.text: From everlasting I was appointed, from the beginning, before the earth existed.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s timeless origin hints at the pre-existence of Christ (cf. John 17:24).

verses.text: When there were no depths, I was brought forth, when there were no springs abounding with water.
verses.comment: Imagery refers to the foundational stages of creation—before chaos or order, wisdom was present.

verses.text: Before the mountains were shaped, before the hills, I was brought forth;
verses.comment: Again, wisdom predates creation, supporting the idea of the divine Word existing eternally with God.

verses.text: before he had made the earth with its fields, or the first dust of the world.
verses.comment: Links back to Genesis creation accounts showing wisdom active from the beginning.

verses.text: When he established the heavens, I was there; when he drew a circle on the face of the deep,
verses.comment: Wisdom present at the act of creating the heavens strongly echoes the Logos’ work in John 1:1-3.

verses.text: when he set the clouds above, when he fixed the springs of the deep,
verses.comment: Further detail of the cosmic order, showing wisdom’s intimate involvement at every stage.

verses.text: when he assigned to the sea its boundary, so the waters would not transgress his command, when he marked out the foundations of the earth,
verses.comment: Wisdom participates in the order and governance of creation, signifying a divine master plan.

verses.text: then I was beside him, as a master craftsman; and I was daily his delight, rejoicing always before him,
verses.comment: The role of ‘master craftsman’ is highly Christological. Early Christians saw this as referring to the Word who is with God and is God (John 1:2).

verses.text: rejoicing in his inhabited world, and delighting in the children of mankind.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s joyful presence in creation points to God’s benevolent purposes for humanity.

verses.text: "Now, therefore, children, listen to me: blessed are those who keep my ways.
verses.comment: Obedience to wisdom brings blessing, and those who live according to wisdom partake deeply in God’s promises.

verses.text: Hear instruction and be wise; do not neglect it.
verses.comment: The imperative to listen and obey echoes elsewhere in Scripture, emphasizing that mere hearing is not enough—one must act (see James 1:22).

verses.text: Blessed is the one who listens to me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at my doors.
verses.comment: Remaining vigilant, waiting upon wisdom, is likened to the blessed man of Psalm 1.

verses.text: For whoever finds me finds life and obtains favor from the LORD.
verses.comment: Finding wisdom is equated with finding life—a theme Jesus applies to Himself as the true, living way (see John 14:6).

verses.text: But he who fails to find me injures himself; all who hate me love death."
verses.comment: Rejecting wisdom leads to self-destruction—separation from wisdom is spiritual death.
